Article: One major focus for NIWeek, National Instrumentsâs annual technical conference last week, was autonomous vehicles. Autonomous vehicles require innovation and testing in multiple domains â the sensors, the machine intelligence, the choice of behavior, and, finally, performance of the powertrain, steering, and braking systems to ride safely and comfortably.    While the engineers in us are naturally drawn to the technology, the Day 2 afternoon keynote focused on the unique societal and regulation issues posed by autonomous vehicles. Eric Starkloff, Executive VP of Global Sales and Marketing at NI, led a panel discussion that included three brilliant speakers: Kamal Khouri, VP of Advanced Driver Assistance Systems at NXP Semiconductors, Bryant Walker Smith, Assistant Professor at the School of Law at the University of South Carolina, and Richard Aspinall, Manager of Powertrain Manufacturing at Faraday Future. As an engineer who is intrigued by the public policy alternative implications of technology, I found the discussion fascinating. You can view a video of the discussion, which starts at 10:40.     The observations from Smith, who holds dual degrees in law and engineering, were particularly insightful. He started by challenging widely held perceptions about the law. Many media articles mention states or cities that have passed a law authorizing autonomous vehicles, or something of the like, as if permission is needed. âWe shouldnât assume that we need a law to do something.â Smith pointed out that many of the early tests in California were before the state passed an explicit law. âIn Arizona, home of many of the activities, there has never been a law on automated driving.â        All new technologies solve some previous problems and generate new ones. The massive number of horses required for transportation led to huge manure issues in city streets. Automobiles solved that problem but brought their own pollution problems and accidents. What will be the new issues with autonomous vehicles? Bryant Walker Smith says that they are difficult to predict, but we hope that the sum of new problems is less than the sum of old problems. Image courtesy of National Instruments and Bryant Smith.      Starkloff started the panel discussion by asking about the âelephant in the room,â the accident in Phoenix. In this case, an experimental Uber vehicle, driving in autonomous mode with a safety driver in the car, hit and killed a pedestrian. The consensus of the group was that this was a failure of the test design. The driver didnât react and appeared to be reading a book. Uber has stated that some of the carâs reaction ability had been detuned. Smith added, âWe should be concerned about automated driving, but we should be terrified of human driving.â Smith then quoted the U.S. statistics: 100 Americans die in auto accidents every day; 15 of them are pedestrians.     Iâm not convinced that an attentive driver would have led to another result. Tempe police released the dash video from the accident. The driver had perhaps one second to react to the pedestrian suddenly visible in the headlights. I consider myself a pretty good driver, and I âget into the zoneâ when Iâm behind the wheel, focusing my attention on driving. I had a similar experience with a deer on a dark two-lane road in Wisconsin one night. Suddenly, a deer was lit by the headlights. I had perhaps a second, not two, to react. I slammed on the brakes hard, keeping the SUV straight to avoid overturning. Both the deer and the front of my car were destroyed. Would brighter headlights have helped? Not much. We know from basic physics that the light reflected back from headlamps is reduced by the fourth power of the distance, leading to only marginal visibility increases with higher luminosity. This accident scenario is one in which autonomous vehicles, with advanced sensing equipment like LIDAR, should react earlier, better, and more safely.     Smith added, âCrashes are inevitable, but that doesnât mean a specific crash is inevitable.â This led to a discussion of how you test to something that is probabilistic. Smith advocated a database of edge scenarios that would be available to all autonomous car designers. To avoid âdesigning to the test,â Smith suggested a rule that any company can use the database as long as they post their results.        A passenger relaxes as his Audi A8 maneuvers through slow-speed traffic. Image courtesy of Audi.      In these discussions, we should be aware that the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) has released a standard describing six levels of driver autonomy ranging from none to full automation. Itâs important to know which level we are speaking about in any one situation. The first production car to reach Level 3 has been announced: the 2019 Audi A8.        The figure above shows the six levels of automation defined by the SAE. Image courtesy of National Instruments.       When asked what is the biggest thing that people get wrong about autonomous driving, Smith answered, âThey think there are driverless cars out there on the road. There are none. These are driver-assistance features.â He continued, âThereâs a big difference between getting on a plane and hearing the pilot say, âHi folks, I will be using autopilot todayâ and hearing the pilot say, âHi folks, you will be using autopilot today. Iâm getting off.ââ    The dream and vision of autonomous vehicles is audacious. Approximately 2.4 million people are injured by auto accidents each year in the U.S., and over 37,000 of those are fatal. Some of these deaths are to those quite young and make a meaningful impact to U.S. life expectancy. Autonomous vehicles aim to take a giant chunk out of those totals. Gasoline- and diesel-based cars are a major source of carbon in our atmosphere. Electric vehicles, combined with renewable energy, aim to make drastic reductions in the carbon footprint. Perhaps the most disruptive long-term effect could be the model of car ownership versus sharing. Along with owning a car comes the issue of parking it. Garages take a significant footprint of new housing. Servicing cars by personally dropping them off is an inconvenient experience. Perhaps there is a new model wherein homes have smaller garages or none at all. Autonomous vehicles act as a customized point-to-point delivery method for mass transportation. Donât drive or canât drive? No problem.    Indeed, autonomous vehicles have a lot of promise. Much of the conversation about autonomous vehicles rightfully focuses on safety. But what is the right level of safety? While perfect safety is ideal, it is not achievable and certainly not optimal. To the extent that current safety levels are replaced by better safety levels, society benefits. Itâs better to bring a replacement technology earlier even if that technology isnât perfectly safe. Statistics vary today, so itâs unclear where we are in that tradeoff. Additionally, while we can have a rational discussion about accident rates and injuries, people donât treat risks solely by their magnitude. Many people have an intense fear of flying, though, statistically, the ride to the airport is often the most dangerous part of their journey. Thereâs a perceived lack of control.    We have a future that promises to be safer, cleaner, and more enjoyable. But the raw fact is that there will be accidents, and people will die in those autonomous driving accidents.
